title: SB 1.18.32-33 | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | 21-04-2023 | Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: In this session we discussed the 32nd and 33rd verses of the 18th chapter of the 1st canto of Shreemad Bhagavatam.
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and an introduction to the verses from Srimad Bhagavatam that will be discussed, focusing on Maharaj Pariksit being cursed.

segments.key_quote: But because the age of Kali was seeking an opportunity to spoil the culture to heritage of the four orders of life, the inexperienced boy gave a chance for the age of Kali to enter into the field of Vedic culture.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the meaning of verse 32, highlighting the power of the brahmana boy Sringi and how the influence of Kali led to a decline in Vedic culture and the rise of hatred among different social orders.

segments.key_quote: We should remember how Kali was trying to enter the kingdom of Pariksit.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on how the degradation of brahmanas allows Kali to influence society and recounts the story of how Maharaj Pariksit initially prevented Kali from entering his kingdom but eventually had to give him shelter in specific places.

segments.key_quote: If we want to protect ourselves against the evil influence of Kali, we should employ 50% of our wealth in propagating Sankirtana.
segments.summary: The speaker suggests using wealth for Sankirtan to protect against Kali's influence, then transitions to discussing verse 33 and Shringi's anger at Maharaj Pariksit's actions.

segments.key_quote: The Brahmanas are considered to be the head and brains of the social body.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the social order (varnashrama), comparing it to the parts of the body, with brahmanas as the head and kshatriyas as the arms, and emphasizes that the system is based on quality (guna) and work (karma), referencing the Bhagavad Gita.

segments.key_quote: People are claiming to be brahmanas without being trained, without being qualified. And that is where the whole system has become topsy-turvy.
segments.summary: The speaker criticizes the modern trend of claiming brahminical status based solely on birthright without proper training or qualifications, leading to a decline in respect for brahmanas and a disruption of the social order due to the influence of Kali.

segments.key_quote: The brahmana should give directions to the other orders of society which are triyas, vashyas and shudras. But brahmanas themselves are not qualified.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by discussing how the deterioration of brahmanas leads to the decline of the entire social order, emphasizing the importance of qualified brahmanas providing guidance, and mentions the upcoming discussion of Shringi's father's reaction before ending the lecture.
